questions.text: The most common cause of peripheral vascular disease is?
questions.solution:
Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of peripheral occlusive vascular disease (POVD). Other causes are trauma and emboli.

Peripheral arterial insufficiency is predominantly a disease of the lower extremities with the superficial femoral and iliac arteries commonly affected.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of peripheral occlusive vascular disease?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittent claudication. 

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

Rest pain is when the disease progresses to a degree that perfusion is severely reduced and cramp-like pain in the calf is felt even at rest. 

A swollen and erythematous limb is seen in critical limb ischemia. When the limb is in the dependent position, there is pooling of blood which causes the limb to appear red and swollen(sunset foot sign).

Buerger's test is done to assess the severity of peripheral vascular disease. In normal individuals, the elevation of the lower limb to a 90-degree angle does not produce any pallor but in affected individuals, even at an elevation of 20-degrees, pallor and venous guttering of the limb can be seen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain in the lower limbs, on walking a certain distance. He noticed that the pain subsides on resting. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Pain is usually felt in the calf muscles
Muscle group affected is below the level of arterial disease
Distance at which pain occurs  varies greatly from day to day
Worsened by anemia or heart failure

questions.solution:
The patient is likely experiencing intermittent claudication due to peripheral occlusive vascular disease.

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day-to-day. The muscle group affected is one anatomical level below the arterial disease.

Boyd’s classification

Class l - Pain on walking but pain decreases on continuation of walking.

Class ll - Pain on walking, but continues to walk despite the pain.

Class lll - Pain forces the patient to stop walking.

Class lV - Pain at rest.
It is worsened by health conditions such as anemia and heart failure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who is a chronic smoker presented to the hospital with intermittent claudication pain of both thigh and buttock region on walking about 500 m. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. Classically, the muscle group affected by claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease.

Intermittent claudication is a feature of chronic arterial disease or occlusion of the artery.  Aortoiliac disease affects the infrarenal aorta and iliac arteries.

Management involves smoking cessation, lifestyle modifications, and treatment of underlying diabetes or hyperlipidemia if present.

For claudication, cilostazol or pentoxyfilline is used. Cilostazol is superior to pentoxyfilline. 

Surgical options include aortoiliac bypass, aortobifemoral bypass, percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA), which can be with or without stent placement, and thromboendarterectomy.

Correlation of clinical findings to the Site of Disease
Aortoiliac obstruction

Claudication in buttocks, thighs, and calves

Bruit over the aortoiliac region

Impotence (Leriche's syndrome)
Iliac obstruction

Claudication of thigh and calf, unilaterally

Absence of femoral and distal pulses

Bruit over iliac region
Femoropopliteal obstruction

Claudication in calf

Femoral pulse felt but distal pulses absent
Distal obstruction

Ankle pulses absent

Claudication in calf and foot

Femoral and popliteal pulses palpable

questions.text: Critical limb ischemia is characterized by all except_____
questions.solution:
Critical limb ischemia is characterized by rest pain and/or ulceration and gangrene. Intermittent claudication progresses to rest pain in critical limb ischemia.

Rest pain occurs with the limb at rest and is felt in the foot; it is exacerbated by lying down or elevation of the foot. Characteristically, the pain is worse at night and it may be lessened by hanging the foot out of bed or by sleeping in a chair. The pressure of clothes on the foot usually makes the pain worse.

Ulceration occurs with severe arterial insufficiency and may present as painful erosion between toes or as shallow, non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the feet, on the shins, and especially around the malleoli. The blackened mummified tissues of frank gangrene are unmistakable and superadded infection often makes the gangrene wet.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.4.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic smoker presents with bluish discoloration of the toe along with intermittent claudication. Which of the following will be the next appropriate investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Chronic smoker presenting with bluish discoloration of the toe along with intermittent claudication is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease and duplex scanning will be the next appropriate investigation.

Duplex Scanning is a major non-invasive technique that uses B-mode ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel. Most scanners now have color coding, which allows detailed visualization of blood flow in a vessel. Different colors indicate changes in the direction and velocity of flow, with areas of high flow usually indicating stenotic lesions.

Other options: 

Option A: CT Angiography (CTA) is more useful in the evaluation of visceral arterial disease (eg. mesenteric ischemia). It can be beneficial in peripheral artery diseases where a duplex scan shows poor images (aortoiliac segment involvement). CTA is not routinely recommended in peripheral artery disease because of concomitant renal dysfunction in these patients which can lead to contrast-induced nephropathy.

Option B: MR Angiography is time-consuming and expensive, hence not done as the next investigation. It is contraindicated in patients with claustrophobia and metallic implants. 

Option C: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive and expensive procedure compared to other investigations. The benefits of DSA are that it provides dynamic arterial flow information and can be combined with a definitive endovascular intervention when indicated. DSA is indicated only when there is a discrepancy in diagnosis or intervention is planned. Complications associated with DSA include bleeding, hematoma, false aneurysm formation, thrombosis, arterial dissection, distal embolisation, renal dysfunction, and allergic reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the investigation of peripheral arterial disease?

choices.text: Duplex scanning is a non invasive technique
On doppler ultrasound a normal artery has a biphasic signal
DSA is now the standard technique used
Computed tomographic angiography is not used routinely to diagnose PAD

questions.solution:
A normal artery has a triphasic signal. The waveform becomes biphasic in mild-moderate stenosis and monophasic in severe stenosis.

Option A: Duplex scanning is a major non-invasive technique that uses B-mode ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel.

Option C: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is now the standard technique whereby the images obtained are digitized by computer and the extraneous background (bone, soft tissues, etc.) is removed to provide clearer images. 

Option D: Computed tomographic angiography (CTA), and conventional catheter-based angiography should not be used for routine diagnostic testing but are performed before potential revascularization. These tests define the anatomy that assists in planning for revascularization procedures.

questions.text: A patient with right leg arterial stenosis is being taken up for angioplasty. Which one of the following is incorrect about this procedure?

choices.text: It is done for patients with rest pain or tissue necrosis
It gives best results for management of stenosis below the knee
Satisfactory dilatation is confirmed by performing angiogram

questions.solution:
Angioplasty gives the best results for medium-sized vessels hence it is preferred for treating the vessels above the knee in peripheral arterial disease.

Angioplasty is indicated in patients with rest pain or tissue necrosis.

Steps of angioplasty: 

  • Patients posted for angioplasty are given aspirin (325 mg) and clopidogrel (loading dose of 300–600 mg). 
  • During the procedure, anticoagulation is achieved by administration of unfractionated heparin, enoxaparin, or bivalirudin (a direct thrombin inhibitor).
  • The femoral artery is punctured under local anesthetic, followed by insertion of a guidewire. The guidewire is negotiated through the stenosis or occlusion under fluoroscopic control.
  • A balloon catheter is then inserted over the guidewire and positioned within the lesion. The balloon is then inflated at high pressure for approximately 1 minute and deflated.
  • Once the angioplasty is done, dilatation is confirmed by performing angiogram.

questions.text: Which is the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass?
questions.solution:
The great saphenous vein (GSV) is the best as it lasts longer than polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), dacron, and human umbilical vein as a graft in a femoropopliteal bypass.

The GSV is the conduit of choice for arterial bypass grafts below the inguinal ligament.

For bypass above the inguinal ligament, while both GSV and PTFE grafts have similar patency rates in the first 2 years, the GSV is superior thereafter and hence preferred over PTFE or any other grafts.

The ipsilateral GSV is the conduit of choice for femoropopliteal bypass. When it is not available, contralateral GSV should be used. Other veins are preferred when both ipsilateral and contralateral GSV is not available and they include a small saphenous vein, cephalic vein, and basilic vein. 

Non-autogenous grafts are used for patients who lack a suitable venous conduit. The most commonly used prosthetic conduit is PTFE. Recent studies have shown that heparin-bonded PTFE is superior to compared to PTFE without heparin.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented with complaints of pain in the right leg right for a day. He has a history of recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following statements are false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Ischemia beyond 6 hrs is usually irreversible
Pain, pallor, pulselessness, and parasthesia/anesthesia are characteristic
Movement of the digits is not affected
Embolectomy and thrombolysis are treatment options

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has acute arterial occlusion and atrial fibrillation can predispose to emboli formation. In acute arterial occlusion, the movement of the digits will be affected and the limb will be cold. Whereas, in venous occlusion, muscle function is not affected.

The leg is often affected with:

  • Pain
  • Pallor
  • Paralysis
  • Loss of pulsation
  • Paraesthesia (or anesthesia).

Embolic arterial occlusion is an emergency that requires immediate treatment. Ischaemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and results in limb loss.

The diagnosis can be made clinically in a patient who has no history of claudication and has a source of emboli, who suddenly develops severe pain or numbness of the limb, which becomes cold and mottled.

questions.text: An elderly man is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe pain and numbness of the left lower limb. He has no previous history of any limb claudication. The limb appears to be cold and peripheral pulses are not palpable. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: CT Angiogram to check for embolus
Thrombolysis with intra-arterial tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) infusion

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of sudden arterial occlusion. The immediate next step is to administer 5000 IU of heparin to prevent extension of clot.

Management of sudden arterial occlusion:

  • Embolectomy with Fogarty’s balloon catheter is the definitive treatment of choice.
  • Thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) can be done in cases where there are no acute signs of limb ischemia as complete lysis of thrombus in tPA infusion is achieved within 24 hours, however, it is cautiously used in the elderly due to risk of bleeding diathesis.
  • A CT angiogram is performed after the procedure to ensure that the flow to the distal leg has been restored.

Ischaemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and may result in limb loss.

Complications of arterial revascularization

  • Compartment syndrome
  • Reperfusion syndrome
  • Ischaemic neuropathy
  • Myoglobinuria
  • Renal failure

Usually, a prophylactic fasciotomy is done in patients undergoing revascularization surgery to prevent compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man had an acute STEMI for which coronary stenting was performed. On the follow-up visit, he reported pain over his toes and discoloration of both feet as shown in the image. His creatinine was also elevated. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atheroembolism. It is also called cholesterol embolism or blue toe syndrome.

Atheroembolism is a condition in which multiple small deposits of fibrin, platelets, and cholesterol debris embolize from proximal atherosclerotic lesions or aneurysmal sites. 

The typical presentation is a patient with ST-elevation myocardial infarction presenting with features of limb ischemia (cyanotic discoloration of the toes with pain and tenderness) following an intraarterial procedure (angioplasty).

Digital vascular occlusion may result in ischemia and the "blue toe" syndrome; digital necrosis and gangrene may develop. Localized areas of tenderness, pallor, and livedo reticularis occur at sites of emboli. Since the atheroemboli tend to lodge in the small vessels of the limbs and may not occlude the large vessels, distal pulses are usually palpable.

Large protruding aortic atheromas are a source of emboli that may lead to limb ischemia, as well as stroke and renal insufficiency. Skin or muscle biopsy may demonstrate cholesterol crystals.

Sharp syndrome, also known as mixed connective tissue disease, is an autoimmune condition with features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Clinical features include Raynaud's syndrome, polyarthritis, myositis, swollen hands, and fingers.

questions.text: A patient with untreated severe peripheral arterial disease comes to the surgery OPD with a right leg as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Usually affects most distal part of a limb
It is a surgical emergency if crepitus is felt on palpation
Occurs when tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of blood stream
Amputation is not done if severe sepsis is present

questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from gangrene of the foot. If there is severe sepsis and if re-establishing blood supply is difficult(revascularization) then amputation is the preferred choice of treatment.

Gangrene refers to death of macroscopic portions of tissue which turn black because of the breakdown of haemoglobin and the formation of iron sulphide.

It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, embolus or arteritis).

Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the bloodstream. Wet Gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may be palpated as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms commonly in diabetic foot problems.

questions.text: A 51-year-old, diabetic patient presents with the following features during a village health camp. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Due to immunosuppression caused by elevated glucose levels
Repeated injury leads to Charcot's foot
Glycemic control and antibiotic therapy is first line managment
Sensory nerves are affected in the late stage of disease

questions.solution:
The image and clinical scenario are suggestive of diabetic gangrene of the foot. It is accompanied by sensory loss in the early stage of the disease and motor involvement in the late stage. 

Diabetic gangrene is caused by a combination of three factors:

  • Ischemia secondary to macrovascular disease and microvascular dysfunction,
  • Peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, which leads to trophic skin changes
  • Immunosuppression is caused by excess sugar in the tissues, which predisposes to infection

Diabetic gangrene is accompanied by loss of sensation and reflexes which lead to repeated injury. There occurs an imbalance between the flexors and extensors of the foot which causes deformities known as Charcot's foot (neuropathic joints).

Initial treatment comprises strict glycemic control and antibiotic therapy. The gangrene is treated by drainage of pus, debridement of dead tissue with local amputation of necrotic digits.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the casualty with complaints of recurrent episodes of syncope and cramping of his left arm. Symptoms mostly occur during his evening badminton practice sessions.  Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Due to occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery
Distal pulse of the affected side is feeble
CT angiography is used to visualize retrograde blood flow

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of subclavian steal syndrome. In subclavian steal syndrome, the first part of the subclavian artery is occluded.

Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by the presence of stenosis in the first part of the subclavian artery either due to atherosclerotic changes or emboli. It leads to reversed flow in the vertebral artery causing cerebral ischemia.

Symptoms include dizziness, syncope on arm exercise. Occasionally, distal pulses in the arm of the affected side are found to be feeble.

Investigations include duplex ultrasonography, CT, and MR angiography.

It can be treated by angioplasty, stenting or by extra-thoracic subclavian bypass.

questions.text: In Paget-Schroetter syndrome which of the following structure is affected?
questions.solution:
In Paget-Schroetter syndrome, the subclavian vein is affected.

Compression of subclavian vein between anterior scalene, clavicle, and the first rib can produce axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis. It results in severe upper extremity pain and swelling,  that is exaggerated by exercise.

Activities such as throwing, swimming, and weightlifting can cause microtrauma of the venous intima that initiates thrombus formation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient who came to the OPD with complaints of pain and numbness of the arm is diagnosed with thoracic outlet syndrome. Which nerve is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
In thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) the lower two nerve roots of the brachial plexus, C8 and T1 are most commonly involved and produce pain and paresthesia along the ulnar nerve distribution.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A resident is trying to elicit symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome in a patient. He asks the patient to keep both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation position and to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period. What is this test called?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome called Roos test (extended arm stress test).

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A young woman presents to the hospital with sudden discoloration of the hands. Which of the following would suggest a diagnosis of acrocyanosis over Raynaud’s phenomenon?
questions.solution:
In acrocyanosis, there is no pain or numbness. In Raynaud’s phenomenon, there is pain and tingling sensation.

Acrocyanosis is a chronic, benign vasoconstrictive disorder. It is due to arterial vasoconstriction and secondary dilation of the capillaries and venules that results in persistent cyanosis of the hands and feet. It can be primary or secondary.

Primary acrocyanosis is more common in females with an onset <30 years. Trophic skin changes and ulcerations do not occur and examination reveals normal pulses.

The disorder can be distinguished from Raynaud’s phenomenon:

  • Because it is persistent and not episodic
  • There is no pain in acrocyanosis whereas in Raynaud's phenomenon there is pain and numbness
  • The discoloration extends proximally from the digits
  • Blanching does not occur

questions.text: A 24-year-old female nurse was on her way to the hospital for her early morning shift. Suddenly she started to notice pain in her fingers which were turning pale and numb after which they turned blue. Which of the following statements are false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Triggered by cold as well as stress
Calcium channel blockers are used for treatment
Mainstay of treatment includes avoidance of triggers
Is not associated with autoimmune diseases

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Raynaud's phenomenon. Secondary causes of Raynaud's phenomenon are seen in association with autoimmune diseases such as scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus etc.

Raynaud’s phenomenon is characterized by triphasic color response of the fingers or toes:

  • Digital blanching or pallor
  • Cyanosis
  • Rubor
Primary Raynaud's phenomenon (Raynaud's disease)

Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon
Idiopathic and more common

Secondary to other conditions (autoimmune diseases, vibration injury)
Women are more commonly affected  No gender predisposition
Age of presentation is between 20 to 40 years Present later in life 
Episodic  -
Affects both hands and feet Affects either both hands or both feet

questions.text:
Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Buerger's disease?
  1. Usually occurs in the age group of 60’s
  2. Thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins
  3. There is absence of brachial pulse
  4. Raynaud’s phenomenon is seen
  5. Affects small and medium-sized arteries
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 3 are false. In thromboangitis obliterans, there is normal brachial and popliteal pulses but reduced or absent radial, ulnar, and/or tibial pulses. It is most common in male smokers, usually under the age of 30 years.

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger’s disease) is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities. 

 The clinical features include a triad of:

  • Claudication of the affected extremity
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Migratory superficial vein thrombophlebitis

Patients frequently have rest pain, ulceration, and digital gangrene.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male construction worker presents with exertional pain and darkening of the skin in both forearms and hands as shown in the image. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day and has no comorbidities  On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial and ulnar pulses are feeble. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chance of success?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco. Key findings in this patient is age < 40 years, smoker, and involvement of upper extremity.

Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder. There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco.

MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion.

The prognosis is poor in individuals who continue to smoke. 

Surgical revascularization is not possible due to extensive vascular inflammation and damage. Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful. If the condition worsens, amputation may be required.

World No Tobacco Day is observed on May 31 every year to highlight the risk associated with the use of tobacco. The annual campaign is to draw global attention to the tobacco epidemic and the preventable death and disease it causes. The theme for this year (2024) is 'Protecting children from tobacco industry interference'.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with cramping pain in the buttocks and erectile dysfunction for the past 6 months. He has no history of bladder dysfunction or fecal incontinence. Examination revealed absent femoral pulses and normal sensory and motor system. How will you surgically manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome. The treatment of choice here is aortobifemoral grafting.

Leriche syndrome is due to occlusion at the aortic bifurcation and is characterized by

  •  Buttock claudication
  •  Impotence  
  • Absence of femoral pulse.
  • No sensory or motor deficit
  • Normal reflexes

Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of Leriche syndrome. 

Differential diagnosis includes

  • Abdominal dissection 
  • Spinal canal stenosis 
  • Spinal disc herniation
Intermittent claudication Neurogenic claudication osteoarthritis
Pain after walking a certain distance Pain after walking or standing for some time Maximum pain on the first step.
Pain quickly relieved on resting. Pain relieved on flexion Pain relieved on resting.

Aortofemoral grafting is done in unilateral iliac vessel occlusion.

Iliofemoral grafting is done for unilateral occlusion of distal common iliac or external iliac artery.

Illiopopliteal grafting is done for femoral artery occlusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for a carotid endarterectomy?
questions.solution:
Dysphonia is not an indication for carotid endarterectomy. Carotid endarterectomy is done in carotid artery stenosis.

Indications of carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients.

CT angiography showing 70% or more stenosis and

  • Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness
  • Contralateral facial paralysis or paresthesia
  • Arm/leg paralysis or paresthesia
  • Hemianopia
  • Dysphasia
